topics.title: Career motivation and the “fake rabbit” trap
topics.summary: Nikhyl opens with an analogy about racing dogs and fake rabbits to warn against defining success as a single milestone. He argues you need a “what’s next” plan to avoid emptiness after achieving a goal.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Nikhyl’s background across Meta, Google, and Credit Karma, and previews the episode’s focus on PM career stages, promotions, leadership blind spots, and mental health. He sets expectations for a wide-ranging career-focused conversation.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Superhuman (email productivity) and Microsoft Clarity (session replay/heatmaps and user behavior analytics).

topics.title: Mentorship scale and coaching “911 calls”
topics.summary: Nikhyl estimates he’s mentored hundreds of PMs, focusing on high-leverage moments like job transitions and urgent workplace dilemmas. He notes several mentees have appeared on the podcast, while keeping names private.

topics.title: Early career: avoid short-term career decisions
topics.summary: Nikhyl explains why optimizing for immediate frustrations (boss, pace, politics) leads to lateral moves and stalled growth. He recommends treating your career like a product roadmap and planning for the “job after next.”

topics.title: Logos vs meaningful building and diverse experiences
topics.summary: They discuss the temptation to chase prestigious company brands versus focusing on building and learning. Nikhyl argues diverse experiences across stages and problem types make you a better builder, while noting big-tech scale experience can matter—especially for executives.

topics.title: Ex-growth companies: definition, risks, and signals
topics.summary: Nikhyl defines “ex-growth” companies as heavily valued, well-funded orgs that still haven’t found real product pull and may face painful resets. He shares how to diagnose PMF via customer pull vs forced acquisition, and when it might still make sense to stay (learning, loyalty).

topics.title: Early PMs: pick a lane and craft your story
topics.summary: Nikhyl advises early-career PMs to become world-class in at least one dimension (craft, market ambiguity, org ambiguity, domain, team leadership, growth). He also stresses building a coherent narrative of impact and learning for future interviews.

topics.title: Mid-career promotions: four common blockers
topics.summary: Nikhyl outlines why promotions stall: lack of advocacy, the next role not existing, impatience with longer leadership timelines, or real development gaps and low self-awareness. He emphasizes diagnosing the true cause before choosing a fix (change scope, change manager, or change yourself).

topics.title: Getting real feedback and building feedback safety
topics.summary: They discuss how to distinguish “not seen” from “not ready” by seeking informal, candid feedback beyond formal systems. Nikhyl shares tactics: triangulate perspectives, listen without defensiveness, repeat feedback back clearly, and publicly credit people who help you improve.

topics.title: Why managers struggle and how new managers succeed
topics.summary: Nikhyl argues tech under-trains managers, creating widespread leadership skill gaps. For new managers, he recommends learning to share the steering wheel (sidecar model) and earning the right to manage by being invited into specific areas where you can help.

topics.title: Senior IC path: why it’s growing and valuable
topics.summary: They explore the rise of senior IC tracks in product, driven by post-hypergrowth realities and the need for deep builders rather than accidental managers. Nikhyl predicts IC paths will solidify and become a durable correction to a long-standing industry “bug.”

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Eppo, an A/B testing and experimentation platform for modern growth teams.

topics.title: Community as the missing manager training layer
topics.summary: Nikhyl argues communities (inside or outside companies) are a powerful way to learn management through safe, authentic peer exchange. He describes starting a CPO community during the pandemic that scaled from a small group to dozens of members sharing real-time advice.
